graphicslib3D
Class CameraSettingsDialog

java.lang.Object
  java.awt.Component
      java.awt.Container
          java.awt.Window
              java.awt.Dialog
                  javax.swing.JDialog
                      graphicslib3D.CameraSettingsDialog
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.awt.event.ActionListener, java.awt.image.ImageObserver, java.awt.MenuContainer, java.io.Serializable, java.util.EventListener, javax.accessibility.Accessible, javax.swing.RootPaneContainer, javax.swing.WindowConstants
public class CameraSettingsDialog
extends javax.swing.JDialog
implements java.awt.event.ActionListener

This class provides a graphical component for keeping track of camera setting values (location, look-at point, and up-direction) interactively. It maintains internal copies of the current values for these settings, along with accessors to get/set those values.

By default a newly constructed CameraSettingsDialog is invisible. A typical use of the class would be for a program initially to create an instance of the class, setting the internal camera values but leaving the dialog invisible until some user input action requests setting of new camera parameters. At that point the program would invoke setVisible(true) on the CameraSettingsDialog, which will display the current set of (internal) camera setting values and allow user to change those values via textboxes in the dialog. When the user presses OK, RESET, or CANCEL on the dialog, the current internal camera settings are updated as appropriate and a "status flag" is set indicating what action the user took. The calling program can then check the status flag to determine what action the user performed, and can invoke accessors to obtain the current dialog setting values.

The dialog is modal; when it is made visible then the user must press one of the buttons on the dialog before the invoking program (the thread which invoked setVisible(true)) is allowed to continue.

If the user presses the RESET button then the internal camera settings are reset to default values. The creating program can use method "setDefaultValues()" to control what values get stored on a Reset action.

Note that the creating program should not create a new CameraSettingsDialog for each user request to set the camera; doing so will result in a dialog which always contains the default settings. Rather, a CameraSettingsDialog should be created once at the beginning of the program and then simply made visible (by invoking setVisible()) each time the user wants to input new camera values.

Note also that this class does not maintain or change any actual camera; it simply provides a graphical mechanism for maintaining and desired camera setting values. It is the responsibility of the user program to create and maintain a camera, including updating the camera each time the user changes the CameraSettingsDialog values.

Author:
John Clevenger

Method Detail

getCameraLocation

public mathlib3D.Point3D getCameraLocation()
Returns a Point3D containing the camera location as currently defined within the CameraDialog. Note that it is the user's responsibility to insure that the actual camera location in the user's program matches the internal dialog value.

getCameraLookAt

public mathlib3D.Point3D getCameraLookAt()
Returns a Point3D containing the camera "look-at" point as currently defined within the CameraDialog. Note that it is the user's responsibility to insure that the actual camera look-at point in the user's program matches the internal dialog value.

getCameraUp

public mathlib3D.Point3D getCameraUp()
Returns a Point3D containing the camera 'up' direction as currently defined within the CameraDialog. Note that it is the user's responsibility to insure that the actual camera 'up' value in the user's program matches the internal dialog value.

setCameraLocation

public void setCameraLocation(mathlib3D.Point3D newLocation)
Sets the camera location value stored in this dialog object to be the specified location. Note that it is the user's responsibility to insure that the actual camera location in the user's program matches the specified newLocation.

setCameraLookAt

public void setCameraLookAt(mathlib3D.Point3D newLookAt)
Sets the camera look-at value stored in this dialog object to be the specified look-at point. Note that it is the user's responsibility to insure that the actual camera look-at value in the user's program matches the specified newLookAt value.

setCameraUp

public void setCameraUp(mathlib3D.Point3D newUp)
Sets the camera up-direction value stored in this dialog object to be the specified up direction. The specified newUp Point3D is interpreted as a vector from the origin to the specified point; the resulting vector indicates the "up direction". Note that it is the user's responsibility to insure that the actual camera "up direction" in the user's program matches the specified newUp value.

resetCameraSettings

public void resetCameraSettings()
Resets the camera parameters in the dialog to their default values. If the user has not explicitly set the default values by calling method setDefaultValues(), then an internal set of defaults are used.

getStatus

public int getStatus()
Returns the CameraSettingsDialog "status flag" which indicates what action the user took most recently when the dialog was made visible. The returned value can be compared with the class-defined constants USER_OK (the user pressed the "OK" button), USER_RESET (the user pressed the "Reset Camera" button, and USER_CANCEL (the user pressed the "Cancel" button) to determine the most recent user action.

setDefaultValues

public void setDefaultValues(mathlib3D.Point3D defaultLocation,
                             mathlib3D.Point3D defaultLookAt,
                             mathlib3D.Point3D defaultUp)
Sets the default values for the camera parameters in the dialog to the specified values. Any subsequent call to resetCameraSettings() will reset the camera parameters contained in the dialog to the specified values.

actionPerformed

public void actionPerformed(java.awt.event.ActionEvent e)
Respond to Action Events from Dialog buttons (OK, Reset, Cancel).

Specified by:
actionPerformed in interface java.awt.event.ActionListener
